migration_period_germanics.name: Migration Period Germanics (250 - 561 AD)
migration_period_germanics.description: The Germanics (Mostly, Goths, Visigoths, Suebi, and Vandals) were a hostile, frontier people during the beginning of this era. They would often be strong allies or enemies of the Romans during this period, with their allegiances being decided by what they viewed as the best opportunity.

ostrogoths.name: Ostrogoths (400 - 561 AD)
ostrogoths.description: After breaking away from the collapsing Hun Empire, they migrated towards the Byzantine Empire, hoping for a rich area to be carved out for them. Sadly, Thracian Goths were already in position and the Byzantine did not have more resources or land to spare. After much struggle, a deal was arranged where they would be given legitimately if they 'liberated' Italy and swore loyalty to the Emperor in the East.

gepids_lombards.name: Gepids and Early Lombards (450 - 774 AD)
gepids_lombards.description: These two cultures lived in what is now North Western Germany. Due to the chaos of the period, and the intrusion of other warrior cultures, they moved increasingly south over time. The two clashed in what is now Austria, and the victorious Lombards fled their 'allies' into what is now Northern Italy. They remained there for centuries.

vandals.name: Vandals (442-535 AD)
vandals.description: A central European people who fled the Huns and then captured much of Northern Africa. They are known for their hatred for the javelin, their dislike for fighting on foot, and their love of the cavalry spear.

west_goths.name: Visigoths (475-720 AD)
west_goths.description: While sackers of Rome, the Visigoths conquered much in Gaul, and retained control of 'Spain' till the 8th century. Unlike their various Germanic 'cousins', they were more flexible in their fighting styles, but were praised for their talent with the javelin thrown from horseback.

burgundians.name: Burgundians (250-532 AD)
burgundians.description: While sackers of Rome, the Visigoths conquered much in Gaul, and retained control of 'Spain' till the 8th century. Unlike their various Germanic 'cousins', they were more flexible in their fighting styles, but were praised for their talent with the javelin thrown from horseback.

germanic_warriors.name: Germanic Warriors
germanic_warriors.description: Under many of the Germanic rulars of the time, The Romans, with their Catholicism, were isolated to the civilian world. More than one source tells of Gothic women being chastied for letting their boys learn to read. The fewer (Compared to Romantics) Germanics were set apart to be warriors; while their swords, mail, and even horses they had made them proud and boastful, eager to prove their worth, and unwilling to be a coward in front of others.

trusted_germanic_warriors.name: Dugundiz Germanic Warriors
trusted_germanic_warriors.description: The Dugundiz (Trusted, Capable) were the freeman and warrior class who having finished their young adulthood, now were experianced fighters of reasonable skill.

trusted_burgundian_warriors.name: Dugundiz Burgundian Warriors
trusted_burgundian_warriors.description: The Dugundiz (Trusted, Capable) were the freeman and warrior class who having finished their young adulthood, now were experianced fighters of reasonable skill.

mount_trusted_goth_warriors.name: Gothic Lancers
mount_trusted_goth_warriors.description: The Dugundiz (Trusted, Capable) were the freeman and warrior class who having finished their young adulthood, now were experianced fighters of reasonable skill.

lowborn_spear_levy.name: Peasant Spear Levy
lowborn_spear_levy.description: Due to the plentiful supply of landless men, spears, and shields; it is likely that if the Germanics were involved in a battle that required them to defend their lands, rather then raid those of another, they would attempt to form a basic spear levy as was common at the time. While the Germanic culture was full of raids and tribal warfare, it was the landowning, 'freemen' who had experiance and equipment.

former_foederati.name: Former Foederati
former_foederati.description: The 'Foederati' (The term comes from a Latin word for 'treaty'), were often allied 'barbarian' peoples or tribes that were bound by treaty and subsidized with land, money, or resources; to act as a 'buffer force' or mercenaries.

former_foederati_veterans.name: Former Foederati Veterans
former_foederati_veterans.description: As time passed, warriors would gain renown, experience, and wealth. This meant better equipment and fighting ability.

bagaudae.name: Bagaudae
bagaudae.description: Bagaudae (Celtic for 'fighters', Latin for 'brigands'), were revolting peasant warriors. Many of these uprisings were put down, but eventually some of them managed to time themselves with a barbarian invasion. The causes of unrest often were: excessive taxation, forced labor, and being treated as property.

goth_bagaudae.name: Rioting Bagaudae
goth_bagaudae.description: Bagaudae (Celtic for 'fighters', Latin for 'brigands'), were revolting peasant warriors. Many of these uprisings were put down, but eventually some of them managed to time themselves with a barbarian invasion. The causes of unrest often were: excessive taxation, forced labor, and being treated as property.

skirmishers.name: Landless Skirmishers
skirmishers.description: A band of the impoverished, landless men who could only bring the clothes on their back, a short blade or club, and some ranged weapons.

light_tribal_warriors.name: Light Tribal Warriors
light_tribal_warriors.description: As the Germanic Cultures conquered other peoples and tribes, expanding their armies, some of these people fought as allies or subordinants before they had fully been assimilated or abandoned. The Gepids and Lombards included Saxons and Slavs in some of their armies.

tribal_warriors.name: Tribal Warriors
tribal_warriors.description: As the Germanic Cultures conquered other peoples and tribes, expanding their armies, some of these people fought as allies or subordinants before they had fully been assimilated or abandoned. The Gepids and Lombards included Saxons and Slavs in some of their armies.

basque_skirm.name: Basque Warriors
basque_skirm.description: The 'Basque'/'Gascon' people lived around the present day borders of France and Spain. Historically, they were mostly ignored by the Romans and those around them. When others did notice them and try to conquer them, they put up fierce resistance. They were eventually conquered, and even before that, plenty of them saw employment as mercenaries.

basque_light_horse.name: Basque Light Horse
basque_light_horse.description: The 'Basque' people lived around the present day borders of France and Spain. Historically, they were mostly ignored by the Romans and those around them. When others did notice them and try to conquer them, they put up fierce resistance. They were eventually conquered, and even before that, plenty of them saw employment as mercenaries.

comitatus.name: Comitatus
comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

burgundian_comitatus.name: Comitatus
burgundian_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

shield_mount_comitatus.name: Shielded and Mounted Comitatus
shield_mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

mount_comitatus.name: Mounted Comitatus
mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

shield_vandal_comitatus.name: Shielded Vandal Comitatus
shield_vandal_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

models.name: Comitatus
models.notes: WAB:GG and Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian) both agree that thrusting spears are in and javelins are out for the Vandals.

vandal_comitatus.name: Vandal Comitatus
vandal_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

mount_eastgoth_comitatus.name: Mounted Ostrogoth Comitatus
mount_eastgoth_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

eastgoth_shield_mount_comitatus.name: Shielded and Mounted Comitatus
eastgoth_shield_mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

models.name: Comitatus
models.notes: WAB:GG and Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian)both lists the East Goths as using barding, likely copied from the Romans or Persians.

burgund_shield_mount_comitatus.name: Shielded and Mounted Comitatus
burgund_shield_mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

mount_franci.name: Mounted Franci
mount_franci.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those with more money and resources.

franci.name: Franci
franci.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those with more money and resources.

vandal_franci.name: Vandal Franci
vandal_franci.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those with more money and resources.

models.name: Franci
models.notes: WAB:GG and Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian) both agree that thrusting spears are in and javelins are out for the Vandals.

italian_militia.name: Italian Communal Militia
italian_militia.description: While northern Italy had plenty of reasonable or even good spear militia, the poorer or less trained members of its militia armies were meager.

warrior_elite.name: Warrior Elite
warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

mount_warrior_elite.name: Mounted Warrior Elite
mount_warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

vandal_warrior_elite.name: Vandal Warrior Elite
vandal_warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

models.name: Warrior
models.notes: WAB:GG and Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian) both agree that thrusting spears are in and javelins are out for the Vandals.

mount_westgoth_warrior_elite.name: Mounted Visigoth Warrior Elite
mount_westgoth_warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

models.name: Warrior
models.notes: Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian) lists the West Goths as being quite talented with throwing spears from horseback.

veteran_westgoth_warrior_elite.name: Veteran Visigoth Warrior Elite
veteran_westgoth_warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

models.name: Warrior
models.notes: Hans Delbruck (Super hardcore Geramn historian) lists the West Goths as being quite talented with throwing spears from horseback.

eastgoth_mount_warrior_elite.name: Mounted Warrior Elite
eastgoth_mount_warrior_elite.description: Among the 'Freemen' were 'warriors' who had obtained greater experiance and training. Those who had volunteered for raids or campaigns, or survived various 'calls to muster' would find opportunity to become full time warriors or even warrior nobility.

mount_kontos_elite.name: Mounted Kontos Elite
mount_kontos_elite.description: The Kontos was a large spear desended from those used by the Greek Hoplites. Even when shrunk down for use by men riding horses, it was still a huge and fearsome weapon, requiring both hands.

eastgoth mount_kontos_elite.name: Mounted Kontos Elite
eastgoth mount_kontos_elite.description: The Kontos was a large spear desended from those used by the Greek Hoplites. Even when shrunk down for use by men riding horses, it was still a huge and fearsome weapon, requiring both hands.

freemen.name: Freemen Infantry
freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

later_freemen.name: Freemen Milita
later_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

archer_freemen.name: Freemen Archer Milita
archer_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

mounted_freemen.name: Mounted Freemen
mounted_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

veteran_italo_franci.name: Veteran Franci Militia
veteran_italo_franci.description: Among the Italo-Lombards, some of the Franci militia became wealthy and well trained enough, to be a sort of 'elite militia'.

italian_milites.name: Italian Milites
italian_milites.description: The milites (Previously a Roman term for 'soldier) were a professional soldier class, who often fought on horseback, as had increasingly been the tradition and focus of the Lombards over the previous few hundred years. While similar to the 'knights' of later periods, which this class would evolve into (Especially for the Normans), they focused less on the thrusting spear or lance, and more on the throwing spear and sword.

alan_nomad_archer.name: Alan Tribal Allies
alan_nomad_archer.description: The Alans were a Turkic/Iranian people from the Caucasus. They became spread over a wider area and assimilated into several other cultures, sometimes as subjects and sometimes as mercenaries.

dux.name: Dux
dux.description: Dux, was a latin word meaning 'leader' or 'general'. The Dux made up the upper echelons of power in Germanic society, and the word would evolve into the familiar 'Duke'.

gastald.name: Gastaldo
gastald.description: As paid officials with direct allegiance to the roving Lombard kings, a gastald was an official with civil, military, and judicial power over an urban area.

comes.name: Comes
comes.description: A Comes (plural, comites), was another latin word, like 'Dux'. This word meant 'companion', but increasingly among late Romans and 'Migration Era' Germanic peoples, meant 'military leader'. This word eventually evolved into the term 'count' and became a rank of nobility.

bishop.name: Bishop
bishop.description: As the Germanics christianized, Christianity (The Germanics were not always Catholic) became a center of their lives. The Church had access to so much wealth and lands, that some of its officals assembled their own armies and operated as warlords.

priest.name: Christian Priest
priest.description: For the lives of rural living people, religion has always been at the center. During these dark and desperate times, for many in Europe, the Christian faith was the only hope they had.

fierce.name: Fierce
fierce.description_short: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.description: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.flavor: During the early Dark Ages, some units were exceptionally eager to 'run down' or 'run through' the enemy.

trample_them.name: Trample Them
trample_them.description: Whenever this unit does a group activation with a unit or uses 'Field Orders' on a unit, that unit gets 'superior_cavalry' for the rest of the round.

rex_italiae.name: Rex Italiae
rex_italiae.description: Unless the enemy is the 'Late Romans (400-500 AD)' or Early Byzantine Empire: this army can recruit or use any unit from the Late Romans (400-500 AD) faction.

rules.notes: These are redundant because my pushes are not being accepted and I need these rules to work for playtesting.

light_infantry.name: Light Infantry
light_infantry.description: (This unit cannot use 'Spearmen' Rule) Optional: +1 save against ranged attacks made at long range, -1 Save to Melee.
light_infantry.flavor: This unit can choose to fight as skirmishers as a loose formation, or 'close up' to fight as traditional infantry.

furious_charge.name: Furious Charge
furious_charge.description_short: Charge and win, enemy unit breaks
furious_charge.description: (Requires Horse or War Horse) If this unit charges another and 'wins' the first round of combat, the other unit has to roll a break test. If the other unit has 'stubborn' rule, roll a d6, on a 1,2,or 3 the other unit avoids the break test.
furious_charge.flavor: The fury of heavy cavalry was terrifying to those not prepared for the loud pounding of hooves and for the sheer weight of the charge.

superior_cavalry.name: Superior Cavalry
superior_cavalry.description: (Requires Horse or War Horse) This unit may re-roll failed Strength tests when charging or making a Fight reaction (To a Charge).

man_of_god.name: Man of God
man_of_god.description: This unit can be merged with any other unit, that unit may re-roll any failed Courage test when removing Shock once per turn.

spearmen.name: Spearmen
spearmen.description: (Note: Requires unmounted, spear and shield) Should this unit do a 'Hold' action and be charged before it's next turn, it has +1 Strength when performing a Counter-Attack reaction and ignores 'Horseman Warrior Culture'.

pike.name: Pike
pike.description: Should this unit be charged, it has +1 Strength when performing a Counter-Attack reaction and it gets to attack first.

impale.name: Impale
impale.description: (Note: Requires horse or warhorse) This weapon gets +1 AP when used during a Charge.

joust.name: Joust
joust.description: (Note: Requires horse or warhorse) This weapon gets +2 AP when used during a Charge.

warrior_culture.name: Warrior Culture
warrior_culture.description: (Note: Requires attack with melee weapon without 'Reach') This unit gets a +1 Str during a Charge.

mount_warrior_culture.name: Horseman Warrior Culture
mount_warrior_culture.description: (Note: Requires melee weapon and Horse/War Horse) This unit gets a +1 Str during a Charge

otto.name: Otto, The Great
otto.flavor: Otto I, was not the start of his dynasty, but the he was the man who made the Holy Roman Empire what it became and is thought to be the first 'German' Emperor. Otto was a religious man, who showed that mounted archers were no longer the dominant force in Central Europe. Heavy Cavalry and 'Knights' would be the future
otto.description: Upgrade one Dux model with 'Trample Them'.

odoacer.name: Odoacer
odoacer.flavor: In terms of lineage, history only certain that Odacer was some type of German. Only year the Western Empire did not have enough land to pay their Foederati as well as the Legionaries, and did not have any land to spare them. Odoacer led the Barbarians in a revolt, defeated the Romans, won over The Senate, disbanded the Army, paid lip service to the Emperor in the East. He ruled as King of the Italy (Rex Italia) untill he was murdered during a diplomatic meeting.
odoacer.description: Upgrade one Dux model with 'Rex Italiae'.

strategies.name: Going Berserk
strategies.description: A selected unit gains +1 Strength till the end of the turn, but they can't use the turn to move away from the closest enemy.

strategies.name: Terrible Charge
strategies.description: One unit on foot gains the rule of 'furious_charge' till the end of the turn.

strategies.name: Swine's_Head
strategies.description: A selected unit gains +1 AP for all their melee weapons, during a charge.

strategies.name: Veterans
strategies.description: All units of geoguth may, once for the entire battle, choose to reroll all their dice to hit by shooting or melee. All dice must be rerolled, good or bad.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given the Germanics a pool of hardened veterans.

strategies.name: Hurry Hurry
strategies.description: Use after Cavalry makes or attempts a Rushing action. The unit reduces its Shock by one.

strategies.name: Run Them Down
strategies.description: Use when a Cavalry makes a Charge action. The Impact Rule gains +1 AP for the charge.
